Award.AwardTitle: Development of Research-Based Tools for Teaching Quantum Mechanics
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the continued development, assessment, and dissemination of Quantum Interactive Learning Tutorials (QuILT) and peer-instruction tools for advanced undergraduate courses. QuILTs and peer instruction tools are based upon a field-tested cognitive-apprenticeship model of learning and emphasize modeling, coaching, and scaffolding. The following features make them particularly suited for the challenging task of teaching quantum physics: (1) They are based upon research in physics education and pay particular attention to cognitive issues. (2) They consistently keep students actively engaged in the learning process by asking them to predict what should happen in a particular situation and then providing appropriate feedback. (3) They employ visualization tools to help students build physical intuition about quantum processes. (4) They attempt to bridge the gap between the abstract quantitative formalism of quantum mechanics and the qualitative understanding necessary to explain and predict diverse physical phenomena. (5) They are based on systematic investigations of difficulties students have in learning various concepts in quantum physics. (6) Many of the tools can be used in class by the instructors as supplements to lectures or outside of the class as homework or as self-study tool by students. (7) They consist of self-sufficient modular units that can be used in any order that is convenient. To aid instructors, the concept-based and problem-based QuILTs and peer-instruction tools will be keyed with most of the common textbooks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We investigate student difficulties in learning quantum physics. We use research as a guide to develop and assess Quantum Interactive Learning Tutorials (QuILTs) and peer-instruction tools including concept tests and reflective problems to significantly reduce student difficulties.
Based upon research in physics education, the development of the QuILTs and peer-instruction tools is guided by a careful attention to cognitive issues. The research-based QuILTs and peer-instruction tools are suitable for use in a one or two-semester advanced undergraduate quantum mechanics course as supplements to lectures and traditional homework assignments and as a self-paced learning tool. The goal of the QuILTs and peer-instruction tools is to actively engage students in the learning process and to help them build links between the formalism and the conceptual aspects of quantum physics without compromising the technical content. They use visualization tools to help students develop intuition about quantum phenomena. Some of the QuILTs developed, evaluated and disseminated include single photon experiments with Mach-Zehnder interferometer and double-slit experiment. The preliminary evaluations suggest that these learning tools are effective in helping students learn quantum mechanics. We have disseminated these findings via invited and contributed presentations at conferences and seminars and colloquia at various physics departments. We have also disseminated our results via publications in journals and conference proceedings. We have also made our research and research-based learning tools available via physport site on compadre, which is the physics part of the National Science Digital Library.
